R.R, Ellison ESQ, Political Agent, Muscat. 1_r PORBION OPPICB, S.W. 1. 28tli January 1949 CONPIDETIAL (B 1139/1601/91) Dear Sir Rupert, Please refer to your Beapatch No 166 dated 6tli December 1948 regarding the l^iture of the Hindu community in Muscat* 8, I enclose a copy of a letter receired from the Commonwealth Relations Office commenting on the points raised in your Despatch. The next step would appear to be, as the letter suggests, for us to ascertain what proportion of the Hindu community in Muscat would 'become United Kingdom citizens if the amendment referred to is passed. Of course not only the Hindus but other Indian communities in Muscat may be affected and we should take stock of their position also.E Pol 10162/49 Cornmonwealth Relations Office, Downing Street. SO January 1949 Dear Rogers, Please refer to your letter to Harrison of 6th January No B 15892/73/91 regarding Hindus resident in Muscat. 2 It is difficult to say exactly vhat provisions would 'be made with regard to nationality if India went completely out of the Commonwealth, and it is by no means certain that the legislation on the subject would follow very closely the Burma Independence Act, 1947 # The more immediate problem however, arisef from the proposed citizenship provisions of the Indian Constitution read in the light of the British Nationality Act, 1948, There is an official amendment to Article 5 of the Draft Constitution which, if it is passed, will secure Indian citizenship for any Indian in Muscat who, or either of whose parents, or any of whose grandparents, was born in the territory of India. Those Hindus in Muscat who do not fulfil this requirement will, provided their British nationality has been secured by registration at a British Consulate, become United Kingdom citizens under the British nationality Act. It is important therefore to ascertain what proportion of the Hindu community in Muscat will thus become United Kingdom citizens. Perhaps you could make enquiries on this point. The Treaty Department too would be interested; we have had some correspondence with them on the somewhat similat question of Hindus in Burma. Yours sincerely. Sgd (P. H, Cleobury) T.B. Rogers Esq., Eastern Department, Foreign Office. S.W.I.

titleInfo.title: 'File 18/19 Conferment of UK Nationality on Certain Indian and Pakistani Residents in the Persian Gulf'

physicalDescription.extent: There is one item of correspondence in this file. It is followed, reading from the front to the rear of the file, by two enclosures, which are filed in reverse chronological order. A circled serial number in red crayon on the compliments slip at the front of the file refers to an entry in the notes at the rear of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at 1 on the front cover and terminates at 6 on the last folio before the back cover. The numbers are written in pencil and appear in the top right hand corner of the recto page of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file consists of a letter from William Rupert Hay, Political Resident in the Persian Gulf to R E Ellison, Political Agent, Muscat, dated 19 February 1949 asking him to establish how many members of the Hindu community in Muscat had been resident there for over two generations, and whether certain other communities in Muscat originating from the Indian sub-continent considered themselves Indians or Pakistanis. Hay writes that there was no need to take Gwadur [Gwadar] into consideration at that time. The letter encloses copies of correspondence from the Commonwealth Relations Office and Foreign Office dated January 1949 relating to the future of the Hindu community in Muscat, and the proportion of that community that would become United Kingdom citizens under the terms of an amendment to the British Nationality Act, 1948.The covering dates of the correspondence (the main body of papers in the file) are 20 January 1949 - 19 February 1949. The closing date in the overall date range is provided by an entry in the notes at the rear of the file.
